Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Mobile Hands-On Empirical Solution in Science Education for Secondary School
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is developing a new technology-based learning ecosystem to engage secondary students in STEM learning through in-class participatory and self-paced experiments that facilitate discovery and bridge abstract concepts to concrete real world learning experiences. More graduates are urgently needed in the STEM fields; this shift will begin with nurturing an interest in the sciences in the minds of youth at the pre-collegial level. This project is designed to strengthen students' confidence in undertaking the difficult challenges inherent in the STEM fields and to enhance their ability to imagine solutions beyond the classroom. The integrated classroom hardware solution being devised will have plug-and-play simplicity with modular data collection sensors and integrated lesson plans that work together to make learning more tangible. Compatibility with students? smartphones and tablets will make adoption easier and further reduce cost. The project is readily commercializable and expandable with a subscription-based business model. The NSF mission of supporting STEM progress for the broadest educational and social benefits guides this project. It addresses the imperative social need to prepare the next generation to effectively solve STEM problems that have global implications, such as climate change and formulating renewable energy sources.

STEM teachers have expressed the need for hands-on learning tools that do not tax their fleeting time by requiring extensive system-level know-how, that fit their shrinking budgets, that avoid build on top of legacy hardware platforms, and that are wireless and portable. This project will yield a new and affordable technology to bring the Internet of Things and cloud-based research and learning into the science classroom. Innovative and flexible sensor hardware will provide reliability in measurement, true portability, tailored functionality, ease of use and reuse, and expandability. The hardware will have a lean modular design (to avoid equipment redundancies) and will be interoperable across multiple scientific disciplines and across topics within the same discipline. Importantly, it will fulfill the market need for hands-on STEM classroom learning experiences at an affordable price point. Integrated with focused lab problems for targeted STEM instruction, these sensors will optimize size, functionality, usability, reliability, and power consumption to achieve required needs. As the hardware/lesson plan ecosystem gets further refined over the course of this project, the project team will engage ongoing teacher feedback to most effectively guide development through initial design, prototype production, class implementation and feedback, technical and pedagogical review, and future recommendations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The company mission of Labify is to democratize education and empower teachers to empower their students. With the support of this NSF SBIR grant, our efforts for the six months of Phase I work mirrored that mission and moved us through a series of functional prototypes. Specifically, we wanted to take the toys that teachers already demo in the class and retrofit them to be able to collect data and engage students in new and creative ways. We spent considerable time with teachers to learn who they are, what they do every day in their classrooms, what their chronic challenges are, what new tools they long for to overcome those challenges, and where they see attention falling off and student disengagement happening. Our R&D process has been very people-focused, implementing the voiced requests of the dedicated teachers that we met along the way and building rapport with them as a community and as interested future customers.

Adopting a design approach with step-by-step experimentation, we have repeatedly returned to the drawing board to find what will engage students in STEM learning. Labify’s goal is to make STEM concepts spring to life right before students’ eyes and to transform their way of thinking through hands-on discovery. When students make the connection that science concepts are not esoteric, that science surrounds them all the time in the objects they interact with daily, that science is absolutely fundamental to improving the quality of life, a spark is ignited that may help them become a more engaged and informed citizen of the modern world and may even inspire them to a career in STEM.

We proposed to develop a cost-effective solution of flexible, multi-functional, modular sensors that can simultaneously snap into a communication base. This battery-operated base connects wirelessly to mobile devices with just a few clicks. The sensors then attach to repurposed toys and household items to turn them into fully fledged science explorations. The goal of this NSF SBIR Phase I grant was to research commercial and technical feasibility. Through this work, we started the journey of inspiring teachers and students to explore the science that is around them without the need of proprietary and expensive hardware.

Our user-centered design strategy was to keep the team focused on creative functionality and market fit. Complimentary to those efforts, the team addressed technical constraints efficiently in building prototypes for conference display and for beta testing. We attended five STEM-related conferences to gather market research and demonstrate the commercial feasibility of the project. After each round of conference feedback, a new iterative design was carried out; we brainstormed ideas, designed working models, built a representative prototype efficiently and quickly, gathered feedback, and iterated again on the design.

During Phase I, the Labify team conducted initial market research efforts including branding. We created nine 3D printed models that represented a variety of conceptual ideas. We also developed multiple minimum viable products (MVP) for on-site testing. We created packaging for mailing MVPs to several volunteer test groups. Out of the nine conceptual models, we fully developed two of them into functional prototypes to be used in tradeshows and conferences while the remaining seven were used to emphasize form and functionality. Our first prototype was an integrated accelerometer that allowed us to immediately engage with teachers to bridge the idea of attaching sensors to things. We showcased a metallic ruler that a teacher could buy for $1.00 and then use to teach the concept of harmonic motion from the affordable apparatus. The second prototype added a gyro to the implementation with an iOS app that provided multiple experiment selections. We also implemented the second prototype on the flying pig (our chosen mascot) and added that on the listed experiments in the iOS app. According to our survey data, the proposed product was perceived as raising the rigor of an experiment, as introducing meaningful calculations to observed phenomena that felt more tangible to students, and as helpful to build student self-efficacy in understanding the why and the how. Continuing to iterate, our third prototype was the deliverable MVP that was used for in-depth testing. We utilized all six sides for various attachments (1x hook, 1x magnet, 1x force sensor, 1x force sensor, 1x modular displacement sensor, 1x power module). The MVP size and dimensions are currently larger than ideal and the force sensors are permanently attached and not truly modular yet. However, we were able to make the displacement sensor as a modular element, which was enough to showcase the concept of modularity for future usability testing. Finally, we tested our products with eight high school students with great results. In less than five minutes, students were building their own experiment, formulating hypotheses, and using the MVP to validate them.
